Now the big file streaming script is checking the hash of the big, reassembled file in a Web Worker.

I tested it against a 200MB file. When the hash of the big file was being checked, the web page still responded to scrolling and video seeking.

Though it is not necessary to check the hash of the reassembled file, I worked out a way to use Web Workers in ZeroNet's `iframe` without running into any cross origin errors.

If a cross origin error causes `new Worker("async-hash.js");` and `importScripts('asmcrypto.js');` to fail, putting the content of the script into a `blob:` URL can bypass this error.

##How to block a person on ZeroMe
1. Find the public key of the person you want to block.
2. Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
3. Go into that person's folder and look at `data.json`. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
4. Delete all his or her files, including `content.json`. Then immediately make a `content.json` **folder** at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
5. You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.

##Dealing with spammers
If you run a website on ZeroNet, please ban these 3 ZeroMe spammers:
```
"meylody@zeroid.bit": false,
"plac@zeroid.bit": false,
"thejumono@zeroid.bit": false
```

Add them to `data/users/content.json` and sign this file. [Example](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/img/redirect.html?../data/users/content.json)

I put together some very interesting ideas on how to deal with spammers in a distributed network. Many of them are still ideas:

- **Proof of Work:** A hard problem takes a few seconds to solve.
- **Decentralized CAPTCHA:** Everyone generates a CAPTCHA according to the rule of this game.
- **Proof of Contribution:** Want to seed? Want to store? Want to donate?
- **Centralized Approval:** An imperial order by the site moderators.

To proof yourself in a distributed network, you have to give out some information that is not only unique to your state but also easy for everyone to check.

Things to check:
1. The peer is following the common rules.
2. The peer has given out information that can reliably imply what we want it to have.

Example: Decentralized CAPTCHA
1. The peer is generating legit CAPTCHAs. It is not generating random, illegible noises. It is not reusing old CAPTCHAs.
2. Solving the CAPTCHA using a computer is hard, but checking the answer is easy. In this way, giving out the answer implies that a real human being, rather than spammer bots, is writing a post. Everyone can effectively conclude that, because it is easy to check the validity of an answer.

Problem with a Decentralized CAPTCHA idea on ZeroTalk:
1. There is no easy way to check if a CAPTCHA is legit.

An Open Question to Every ZeroNet Contributor

## How to maintain a reasonable balance between storage availability and data availability, using algorithms?

(Updated)

When I read the homepage of bit.no.com, the ZeroNet proxy, I noticed that the proxy found more peers than my own ZeroNet client did. When I clicked on my ZeroMux website to see the peers bit.no.com found, I saw many points that I could not find on my own map. I believe that those extra points were computers that were no longer reachable. (Correction: peer list is updated every 1~4 hours)

Several days ago, the owner of https://onlyzero.net/ , a ZeroNet proxy, received a takedown complaint from a Hong Kong company, forcing the site owner to take down a software cracking site hosted on the proxy. This complaint is the first takedown complaint that makes us be aware of peer reliability in ZeroNet.

ZeroNet chooses which optional file to recycle according to the number of peers the file has. ZeroNet may have included the peers that are "dead," unreachable and very slow, or have other incorrect assumptions on peer reliability. To make a more accurate calculation, ZeroNet's corresponding algorithm should apply a weight to every peer.

### How to define the weight?
Concerns:
- We cannot rely on peers that are "dead," slow and unlikely to **contribute**.
- We cannot rely too much on **major seeders**. When someone tries to take down certain content, he or she will take down the major seeders first.

Aspects to take in, including but not limited to:
- **Connectivity:** the "ping" value of a peer __(but adds to data transfer)__; the speed a peer __(but has insufficient data)__; the ratio of the number of successful connections to the number of all connections made __(requires bigger sample size)__.
- **Contribution:** recent contributions of a peer, observed by ZeroNet itself. __(but varies with respect to network environment)__.
- **Location Diversity:** preserve data availability when massive Internet censorship takes place __(but this paranoid factor consumes much computational power)__.

Mathematical Fairness:
- Since we cannot rely too much on major seeders, the weight should not be greater than 1. This cut off avoids over-evaluating big seeding peers.
- Since ZeroNet evaluates data availability based on its observation of its own network environment, ZeroNet may run into some false positives. We should also find a way to cross validate evaluations. (Hard)

Simple Explanation:
- 1 slow peer = 0.5 normal peer
- 1 very slow peer = 0.25 normal peer
- 1 fast peer = 1 normal peer (reduce major seeder dependency)
- 1 very fast peer = 1 normal peer (reduce major seeder dependency)

### Viability
Calculating the weight defined above requires a lot of information, and it is costly to gather all these information only to calculate weights. Perhaps we can take a more heuristic approach, at the beginning, assuming all peers has a weight of 0.9, and changing the weight value when latest information is available.

This algorithm may be too paranoid, but it can be helpful when there are disruptions targeting the ZeroNetwork going on.

Adapted from the slides for a talk by Feross Aboukhadijeh, the WebTorrent developer, at JSConf.Asia 2014

(Principles to follow when sharing files over P2P network)
- **Tit-for-tat:** Help peers that help us.
- **Download rarest pieces first:** Get more attractive and Preserve torrent health.
- **Preempt slow peers:** Request same piece from multiple peers (to get more speed and balance more load).

Feross Aboukhadijeh:
A torrent file is:
```
{
    name: "My Awesome File",
    pieces: [
        "46b6c78b63b77878b88abe92de2a20f914c8629d",
        "bf180cfeeb0ca81b0a2297ee82225c161cae58eb",
        "8aaf5d93eb34ac35df449bce866508c92c36ecbd",
    ],
    announce: "http://tracker.example.com"
}
```
An "infohash" is:
The message digest of the data above (except announce)
- - -
ZeroMux File Sharing Service's similar design:
file.json:
```
{
    name: "My Awesome File",
    pieces: [
        [512000, "46b6c78b...sha256...be92de2a20f914c8629d"],
        [512000, "bf180cfe...sha256...97ee82225c161cae58eb"],
        [512000, "8aaf5d93...sha256...9bce866508c92c36ecbd"],
    ],
    announce: (hand over to ZeroNet)
}
```
Piece hashes are used to prevent file damage. ZeroNet is responsible for checking file integrity against various attacks.

To help you understand how complicated it is to stream videos over ZeroNet, I made a diagram to demonstrate what happens if you seek a video.

From top to bottom:
- A big file is reassembled from file chunks.
- A simulated stream is made to provide an abstraction layer between chunks and offsets.
- An MP4 remuxer is made to load video and audio frames.

From bottom to top:
- An event is dispatched, with the time stamp to seek to.
- Time stamp is converted into offset.
- Offset is then converted into chunk index
- The downloader will then download that chunk.

The Tor Project is working very hard implementing the next generation of Tor Onion Services.

https://blog.torproject.org/blog/whats-new-tor-0298

### Shared Randomness

We've talked about this before but now it is a reality. At midnight UTC every day, directory authorities collectively generate a global random value that cannot be predicted in advance. This daily fresh random value is the foundation of our next generation onion service work coming soon to a Tor near you.

In the consensus file, they will look like this; if all goes well, at 00:00 UTC, consensus will have a new one:


    shared-rand-current-value Hq+hGlzwAVetJ2zkO70riH/SEMNri+c7Ps8xERZ3a0o=
    shared-rand-previous-value CY5TncVAltDpkBKZUBYT1canvqmVoNuweiKVZIilHfs= 


Thanks to atagar, the Stem Library version 1.5.0 supports parsing the shared random values from the consensus. See here for more information!

Voluntarily, we haven't exposed those values to the control port yet and will wait for a full stable release cycle in order to make sure it's stable enough for a third party application to use them (https://trac.torproject.org/19925).

While nofish and several contributors are making ZeroNet backend more CSRF tolerant, fellow developers need to make sure they follow these usability and security practices:

- Use `target=_top` attribute on cross site links and clearnet links, otherwise the websites they link to will be opened in a sandbox that breaks site functionality.
- Avoid loading resources directly from clearnet. If you really need to do so, make sure you strip sensitive data from these clearnet requests, and ensure your site still works when clearnet connection is blocked.
- Avoid putting a Zite into an iframe. It will not work.

####  Async JavaScript and Sync streams
In JavaScript, operations of reading and writing data are async, but programs that use streams expect streams to be sync. Programmers do not expect `readUint32()` to be async.

The proposed solution is obvious: pause execution before stream calls back. This solution is currently very hard to implement in JavaScript.

It is impractical to use a callback every time you read a byte from the stream.

Fortunately, the `async` and `await` keywords are coming to Firefox 52.

[This commit of ZeroMux](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux) contains new video streaming APIs and a simple video player. To use these APIs and see your videos playing, [download](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux/archive/master.zip) the newest master branch.

Extract the new package to a new directory. Run `./wizard.py` and upload an MP4 video file. If this file is encoded properly, ZeroMux should put a `moov_box.dat` at the place where `file.json` is located.

Like what I promised, video streaming has never been easier.

Now use a good text editor to hack the source code of `loader/example-player.html`. Go to line 49:
```
49|  var args = streamArgs(
50|      "path/to/file.json",
51|      "path/to/moov_box.dat",
52|      'video/mp4; codecs="avc1.______, mp4a.__._"'
53|  );
```

Change the parameters so that they reflect your settings.

Save your changes and go to http://127.0.0.1:18905/loader/example-player.html

You should see your video playing and buffering.

Now toggle web developer tools and see what's behind the scene. ZeroMux loads every chunk of file and makes it into smooth streaming format. Each component of ZeroMux works together to produce what you are watching.

If you ever wondered why it took so long for me to write ZeroMux -- this is how ZeroMux conceptually works.

An _abstraction layer_ was made to convert offsets to chunk indicies, so that a big file can be treated as a stream, regardless how this "file" is represented.

Below the abstraction layer is a general purpose MP4 multiplexer, which means its only job is to convert an MP4 stream to a _smooth streaming_ MP4 stream, and it makes no assumptions about how an MP4 "file" is represented.

On the left: web developer console.

### Video Streaming over ZeroNet is limited. How can I stream a long video like this?
[Download](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux/archive/master.zip) the latest master branch of ZeroMux from [GitHub](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux).

Choose an MP4 video file you'd like to play. [Here](https://nickdesaulniers.github.io/mp4info/) you can check your MP4 file and get a _codec string_.

That page should say: `is fragmented: false`

That page should say:
`MediaSource.isTypeSupported('video/mp4; codecs="______"'); // => true`
(this is your _codec string_)

Upload your MP4 file via ZeroMux.

Then hack the source code of `loader/example-player.html`. Find the `<script>` tag at the end of file. Fill in the blanks so that the parameters reflect your own setting.

See it working!

### How to share files privately over ZeroNet (with ZeroMux)

Principles:
1. Data confidentiality. Privacy matters.
2. Completely over ZeroNet. You can share files via other means, but that is not the focus of this tutorial.

Steps:
1. _Key Agreement:_ send a ZeroMail to your friend, exchange your encryption keys. The protocol of ZeroNet is robust enough to protect data integrity. If you think ZeroMail is unsafe (which is really not the case), you can ask your friend to use public key encryption.

2. _Encryption:_ Encrypt your file with external tools. 7-Zip / PeaZip / GPG

3. _Chunking and Signing:_ Set up your ZeroMux site.

4. _Download:_ Send a ZeroMail to your friend. Tell him your site address, so that he can download the file. Keep this address private. Remember to tell your friend to inform you when he finishes downloading and verifying your file.

5. _Clean up:_ Simply delete your site.

Quick Questions:
1. _Q:_ Will the trackers know my site address?
    _A:_ No. Your address will always be hashed before it is posted to the trackers.

2. _Q:_ How can data integrity be ensured?
    _A:_ Data integrity is ensured via the digital signature algorithm used by Bitcoin.

3. _Q:_ Why do I need to encrypt my file?
    _A:_ ZeroNet protocol cannot protect data confidentiality against active attackers.

4. _Q:_ What about port forwarding?
    _A:_ Such technique requires the file hosting peer have open ports for incoming connections. It is recommended that both of you use Tor Hidden Service mode.

5. _Q:_ What about traffic correlation attacks?
    _A:_ Because you are sending out a large amount of data, you might be susceptible to traffic correlation attacks, which can be used to deanonymize you. Deliberately throttling the upload bandwidth of Python interpreter might mitigate traffic correlation attack. I2P integration might also mitigate this attack. (This is why I2P support is important)

I tried RetroShare's Dark Net mode. The Dark Net support of RetroShare is **limited** and **hard to configure.** RetroShare requires the user to create a Tor Hidden service or a I2P server tunnel in order to use the Dark Net mode. The only parameters you can change in RetroShare is its listen address and the proxy address it wants to use for outgoing connections.

I am using PurpleI2P, and I followed their [tutorial](https://github.com/PurpleI2P/i2pd/wiki/Using-with-Retroshare) of creating a I2P hidden service. 
`RetroShare => xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.b32.i2p:51111`

I can verify it with python http server `python -m SimpleHTTPServer 51111` and put that tunnel address in the address bar.

Perhaps I can create another server tunnel via this manual method and let ZeroNet use it. Too bad there are no I2P trackers added and there aren't any other peers out there.

### ZeroMux Update - Videos Become Seekable

The abstraction stream in ZeroMux is [seekable](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/usage/with-abstract-stream/) and asynchronous, which allows you to port applications to ZeroNet.

[Added video seeking support!](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux/commit/00c374f6b79225c84c85b47aaa78eb128624bc89#diff-5ed7128da09cd802881f62c28296b760R540) ZeroMux is able to stream big and long videos. You can now click on any places that don't appear to be loaded on the progress bar. (No demos on ZeroNet unfortunately)

On one day, Mozilla people said, "Since royalty free formats are not supported by Internet Explorer and Safari, Mozilla has decided to support the format anyway."

Starting in Firefox 51, you can [play FLAC files](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Supported_media_formats) directly in Firefox. In addtion, you can MP4 files using the FLAC codec, both with and without Media Source Extensions support.

```
>>> MediaSource.isTypeSupported("video/mp4; codecs=\"avc1.640020, flac\"")
<<< true

>>> MediaSource.isTypeSupported("audio/mp4; codecs=\"flac\"")
<<< true
```

If you have the git HEAD version of FFmpeg, you can put an FLAC file into an MP4 container by running:
`ffmpeg -i flac.flac -strict -2 -acodec copy -vn mp4.mp4`

As fallbacks, we have [aurora.js](https://github.com/audiocogs/aurora.js), [dr_flac](https://mackron.github.io/dr_flac) and [Emscripten](https://github.com/kripken/emscripten).

I wrote a sample FLAC decoding program with [dr_flac](https://mackron.github.io/dr_flac). It turns out that dr_flac is more flexible and more efficient that Audiocog's implementation. The single file FLAC audio decoder runs very fast in Emscripten even with Emterpreter turned on.

I have successfully ported dr_flac to ZeroMux abstraction stream, using Emscripten, which allows the FLAC decoder written in C to work in any modern browser. Each read operation has data overhead, but dr_flac still outperforms Audiocog in this situation.

Resilio Sync is proprietary. Let's talk about some of its free as in freedom and open source alternatives:

### SyncThing
Their website explicitly mentioned that SyncThing is a replacement for proprietary file syncing software and protocol. It works well and it supports Tor. It seems that you have to manually approve and accept every new peer.

### I2P torrent
I like it. It is not so slow as it advertised. You have to install Java Runtime Environment before you can use I2Prouter. PurpleI2P is an alternative implementation in C++.

It is not recommended to use SHA-1 Torrent over I2P due to collision attacks, but many safer file sharing protocol can be run over I2P.

### OnionShare
Endorsed by the Tor Project, OnionShare is for private, secure file transferring. It is not intended to be used as a file sharing tool.

### ZeroNet
The software you are using right now. Use it to set up your own site. Why do I endorse ZeroNet for file sharing? Because, why not?

### IPFS
I haven't used IPFS, because it doesn't officially support Tor. I am aware of a lot of positive comments about IPFS. Some says IPFS and ZeroNet are mutual and wants to marry both. 

### RetroShare
Supports Tor and I2P. Still I can't get it working...

### Tahoe-LAFS
Supports Tor and I2P. Still reading the documentation...

### ~~Tribler~~
Do not use Tribler. Tribler used weak crypto and their _Tor-inspired network design_ was busted by the official Tor Project.

Fuzzer puts "garbage" into a program -> zzzzzzzzzzzzzz. zzzzzzzzzzzz. -> BOOOM program crashed. -> Report this issue -> An unknown bug, gone.

So let's discuss Fuzz Testing! [ZeroTalk thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:3_1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC)

Having **too much fun** [fuzz testing](https://github.com/aoh/radamsa) ZeroNet's FileServer. A majority of found glitches are caused by type assumption. By the way, you should definitely check out how crazy fuzzing algorithms can get.

Fuzz Testing ZeroNet: https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/Fuzzing

Fuzz testing is an efficient way of testing software robustness.

[This file](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/Fuzzing/blob/master/zn_protocol.py) contains a list of malformed requests. Be creative! You can help us come up with more test cases and help improve code coverage!

I conducted a series of fuzz tests against ZeroNet's FileServer. My fuzzing log has been uploaded, and I wrote a report on it. You can read the report at [GitHub](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/Fuzzing/tree/master/Fuzzing Log/Round 1)

Fuzz testing is an automatic method to discover hidden bugs. An efficient fuzzer can take simple input samples and produce malformed input that has a good code coverage.

To help you understand the power of efficient fuzz testing, a blogger ran afl fuzzer against OpenSSL and [reproduced](https://blog.hboeck.de/archives/868-How-Heartbleed-couldve-been-found.html) the Heartbleed vulnerability.

Therefore, crashing software is not only fun. It is crucial in writing stable and resilient programs.

The current code coverage is poor. One way to improve code coverage is to add more input samples. There are currently 26 samples included in the [generator script](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/Fuzzing/blob/master/zn_protocol.py). You can help add more!

With some modification, ZeroNet can now be tested with American Fuzzy Lop. The modified implementation of ZeroNet will deliberately crash once an uncaught exception is thrown. After 4 hours of fuzz testing, AFL found **2800+** crashes (said **10 unique** crashes, but in fact many were counted twice)

- Type error: `list` does not have bound method `replace`
- Key error: `inner_path`
- ASCII decoding error: ASCII codec cannot decode X character.
- File constructor error: `file()` constructor found `\x00` in given path. (Use `io.open` instead?)
- File not found (Should catch this exception)

### Unofficial ZeroMail enhancement proposal
https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/brainstorming

Are you dissatisfied with how the current ZeroMail works? Leave your comment below or in the repo so that we know how ZeroMail can be improved.

- Attempt to get around local storage shortcomings.
- Attempt to put encrypted messages into buckets.
- Attempt to obscure payload size correlation.

Update: I am writing up my ideas of a user data format that can be used in implementing _selective caching_.
```
1DisposableKeyJ3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/
    content.json
    email_1.json
    email_2.json
    ...
```

It involves saving every single email in a _separate_ file. Email senders are _allowed_ to save multiple emails in a single file, but he **must not** put old emails together with new emails. Doing so will not guarantee a longer TTL.

How can you possibly make sure everyone does that? By enforcing rules that are beneficial to the community, we "punish" malicious peers who keep big user data files. The seeding algorithm looks for the oldest timestamp included in an email json file. (1) If the json file is malformed, the **whole** file **must** be discarded. (2) If the _any_ timestamp refers to the future, the **whole** file **must** be discarded. (3) If the _oldest_ timestamp refers to a long time ago (i.e. > 17 days ago), the **whole** file **must** be discarded.

Intel's crappy Remote Code Execution engine, AMT, finally [uncovered its vulnerabilities](https://mjg59.dreamwidth.org/48429.html). True, AMT can be disabled, but what annoys me is the way this management module works:

> When AMT is enabled, any packets sent to the machine's wired network port on port 16992 or 16993 will be redirected to the ME and passed on to AMT - the OS never sees these packets.

What you should do:

- If Intel AMT is explicitly enabled, make your BIOS say that Intel AMT is disabled.

- If you have a non-Intel-powered router (such as a router running on ARM) that is equipped with libre software, you should disable both incoming and outgoing connection which uses AMT protocol's default ports: port 623, 664, 16990, 16991, 16992, 16993, 16994, 16995, 16996, 16997, 16998 and 16999 as described [here](https://downloadmirror.intel.com/26754/eng/INTEL-SA-00075%20Mitigation%20Guide-Rev%201.1.pdf).

- It is time to enforce strict firewall rules on your router. Except Tor bridges, who the f*ck today will use any port in range [444, 1024] to communicate with computers on the WAN part of the Internet?

This implies the only available way to do personal computing today, is to destroy your expensive laptop and run ZeroNet on your GBA.

Python's `zipfile` does not support file deletion. You can't remove files from a zip archive. (Those single-file compression formats do not support mutation either.)

Due to this limitation, if Tamas is going to add compressed user content support, 
- data compression can only be used on old user data, which do not change often
- one archive file per user
- when an old user comes back, all of his data archive got extracted

Besides these strategies, we must rate limit the archiving algorithm and enforce file name rules.

[Unofficial ZeroMail Enhancement Proposal](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/brainstorming) update:
- [Added](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/brainstorming/blob/master/Message%20Packing%20and%20API.md) an email signing and encrypting algorithm proposal.

@12hlearn: ZeroMux was made before the time of Msgpack Streaming, before the time of Optional file manager and before the time of ZeroMe. I understand that ZeroNet lacked a media sharing platform, and that big file support was too complicated to fit ZeroNet's architecture at that time.

If you have ever read through the issue page of ZeroNet, you would have noticed, ZeroMux is actually an implementation of PR [#521](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/521) on application level. I decided to make it JS, because at that time, there was a [huge](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet?tab=overview&from=2016-06-06) [blank area](https://github.com/shortcutme?tab=overview&from=2016-06-06) on ZeroNet's activity graph.

Attempts to make ZeroNet great again have been made by many people, mostly encouraged by this extended period of inactivity. Early developers at that time, @Lola: made ZeroTube, @Bwoi: and @PaintNinja: made the very first music sites on ZeroNet, @Tkarita: who had worked and left first used "ZeroNet big file loader" to share PDF ebooks, and @Eibriel: who came later but became a productive blogger integrated IPFS in his blog. None of them focused on changing ZeroNet's source code, because such ambition of file sharing was way ahead of its time. Urging ZeroNet's sole developer would not work.

Thanks to the hardworking of NoFish and 50+ contributors, now ZeroNet is just a few patches away to support big files at its basic level. It might be ridiculous to you that we early ZeroNet users were working so hard on attempts that look awkward and stupid today, but remember, those are the efforts of us, early developers, to keep ZeroNet alive and make ZeroNet great.
